articles.headline: Port Workers Strike on East and Gulf Coasts
articles.snippet: Members of the International Longshoremen’s Association walked out for the first time since 1977 in a standoff over wages, benefits and job security.
articles.abstract: Members of the International Longshoremen’s Association walked out for the first time since 1977 in a standoff over wages, benefits and job security.
articles.lead_paragraph: For the first time in nearly 50 years, longshoremen on the East and Gulf Coasts went on strike Tuesday, a move that will cut off most trade through some of the busiest U.S. ports and could send a chill through the economy.

articles.headline: Not Just Fun and Games: Politics Edges Deeper Into Livestreams
articles.snippet: As more streamers discuss politics, including major events like Tuesday’s debate, they have become the focus of intense interest for both presidential campaigns.
articles.abstract: As more streamers discuss politics, including major events like Tuesday’s debate, they have become the focus of intense interest for both presidential campaigns.
articles.lead_paragraph: During last month’s presidential debate, Hasan Piker appeared in the corner of the screen on his Twitch channel. With the debate playing live behind him, he interjected sporadically.
articles.byline: By Jessica Testa, Ken Bensinger and Eli Tan

articles.headline: Mexico’s First Female President Takes Office
articles.snippet: A climate scientist and former mayor, Claudia Sheinbaum was inaugurated on Tuesday as the first woman to lead the country.
articles.abstract: A climate scientist and former mayor, Claudia Sheinbaum was inaugurated on Tuesday as the first woman to lead the country.
articles.lead_paragraph: Claudia Sheinbaum took office on Tuesday, the first woman and Jewish person to lead Mexico in the country’s more than 200-year history as an independent nation.
articles.byline: By Emiliano Rodríguez Mega and Natalie Kitroeff

articles.headline: As Crisis Builds, Lebanon’s Government Is Nowhere to Be Found
articles.snippet: Already crippled by years of economic decline, political paralysis and other crises, Lebanon has little but its own citizens’ grit to survive the Israel-Hezbollah conflict.
articles.abstract: Already crippled by years of economic decline, political paralysis and other crises, Lebanon has little but its own citizens’ grit to survive the Israel-Hezbollah conflict.
articles.lead_paragraph: Even for the Lebanese, it can be hard to say where it all went wrong for their tiny, beautiful country.

articles.headline: Biden to Sign Bill Allowing Chip Projects to Skirt Key Environmental Review
articles.snippet: The legislation, which would weaken federal environmental reviews for certain semiconductor manufacturing projects, has divided Democrats.
articles.abstract: The legislation, which would weaken federal environmental reviews for certain semiconductor manufacturing projects, has divided Democrats.
articles.lead_paragraph: More than two years ago, President Biden signed a law that aimed to ramp up the nation’s production of semiconductors by offering generous subsidies and tax credits to companies. Since then, chip manufacturers have invested billions of dollars into new plants across the country.

articles.headline: Can Pro Sports and Drag Queens Coexist? A Mill Town Finds Out.
articles.snippet: A gay couple embraced inclusion after buying an English rugby team. To their surprise, the fans bought in, too.
articles.abstract: A gay couple embraced inclusion after buying an English rugby team. To their surprise, the fans bought in, too.
articles.lead_paragraph: Kaue Garcia and Ryan O’Neill had owned a sports team for no more than six months when they decided the time was right to shake things up. What they needed more than anything else, they felt, was a drag queen.
